intro.p: Still on a quest to determine a mathematical relationship between these two quantities, you collect a set of data points as follows.
where {{x}} denotes the {{xinterp}}, measured in {{xuni}}; and {{y}} denotes the {{yinterp}}, measured in {{yuni}}.

content.p: Four of these five data points exactly fit a linear model y = f(x).
By computing slopes, determine which of the five points is not a perfect fit, and explain your answer.

outtro.p: The point ({{px}},{{py}}) is out of place with the linear model.

content.p: Remove the point you found in part (a). Then, find a slope-intercept equation for the linear model y = mx + b that passes through the remaining four data points.

outtro.p: With that point removed, the remaining points fit the linear model y = f(x) = {{rhs}}.

content.p: In one "when-then" sentence, explain the practical meaning of the y-intercept of your linear model.
(How should we understand the meaning of that number, in terms of {{xinterp}} and/or {{yinterp}}? Include units in your explanation as appropriate.)

outtro.p: The y-intercept is \boxed{ {{b}} }. This means that when {{xinterp}} is zero {{xuni}}, then the {{yinterp}} will be {{b}} {{yuni}}.

content.p: In one sentence, explain the practical meaning of the slope of your linear model.
(How should we understand the meaning of that number, in terms of {{xinterp}} and/or {{yinterp}}? Include units in your explanation as appropriate.)

outtro.p: The slope is \boxed{ {{m}} }. This means that every change of {{mden}} {{xuni}} in the {{xinterp}} is associated with a change of {{mnum}} {{yuni}} in the {{yinterp}}.
